title: Applied Graphical Models
description:
Graphical models are probabilistic models that use a graph-based representation as to the foundation for encoding a distribution over a multidimensional space and a graph that is a compact or factorized representation of a set of conditional independence that holds in the specific distribution. These models were introduced in the late 1970s, and they are used now in many fields to understand cause-effect relationships between variables. In this course, we start by introducing some concepts on graph theory without any direct reference to statistical modeling. We also show the mathematical properties, known as Markov properties, that allow a given graph to read the conditional independence in a multidimensional distribution. We then show different kinds of graphical models: graphical models for contingency tables for discrete data and log-linear models; Gaussian graphical models for continuous data; Bayesian networks to model causality between variables; mixed graphical models for mixed data: continuous and discrete variables; and high-dimensional modeling.

Prerequisites: ECON 117, ECON 135, MATH 120, MATH 222, MATH 225, MATH 241, S&DS 538, S&DS 610, S&DS 612, or permission of the instructor; the ability to work directly with data (basic proficiency in R); and familiarity with probability, statistical inference, regression, and model specification. However, this course can be beneficial for Ph.D. students with no solid math background who need to learn how to analyze time series data for their research. The course can also be audited. Enrollment is limited and requires permission of the instructor.
